ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lectures that were recorded
Lecture was live, but recorded.
I alternated between watching the live lecture and the recorded version.

The live virtual lecture was recorded and made available for students to watch lectures asynchronously. Additionally, virtual discussion sections were held each week by the TA to discuss the material and answer any outstanding questions.
I attended live virtual lecture and watched recorded lectures.
optional virtual non-recorded section

In addition to live, virtual lectures twice each week led by the professor, there were virtual office hours at different times throughout the week, and a virtual discussion section led by the teaching fellow.
live virtual lecture, discussion section.
None. All lectures were done synchronously over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A better understanding of physiology. Don't let a lack of background in anatomy scare you away.
Absolutely great course where you really get out of your comfort zone in terms of
I learned many interesting core concepts about physiology compared across multiple organisms and systems
Physiological mechanisms that underly life's diversity.

I learned a lot about the anatomy of different types of organisms. It was really cool to learn this information and then compare it to the human anatomy. This class was so cool and engaging! I also learned random facts and physiological features of different organisms, which was also very cool.

The first half of the course was a review of important physiological and evolutionary concepts (membranes, homeostasis, phylogenies, etc.) and the second half of the course was an application of these concepts to physiological mechanisms like flight, temperature regulation by lizards, neural circuits of startle responses, and more.
a broad-spectrum overview of the various ways in which evolutionary biology and ecology intertwine with chemistry and physics, some rehashing of basic evolutionary theory

Overall, this course was excellent. I am a graduate student and my program is quite unrelated to comparative physiology, but I decided to take this course out of genuine interest for the subject matter and to aid with medical school preparation. While the majority of the course was shaped around animal physiology, it was great to be able to see the parallels in body systems and evolutionary processes between different species and humans. Even for students who are not studying biology, this course helped me understand evolution through many different lenses and the professor made it easy for me to recognize comparisons and similarities in biology across the animal kingdom.
deepen understanding of concepts and philosophical framework in ecology and evolution. Practice of scrutinizing literature

Taking this course exposed me to so many different aspects of physiology. We learned about muscle coordination, reflexes, metabolism, thermoregulation, reproductive physiology, and a ton of other stuff from guest lecturers (flying snakes????). There is some anatomy involved in this course, and since I had taken E&EB 290 prior to this course, it made more sense than what I imagine it would have been without prior knowledge.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very interesting but everything was weighted very highly for example, if you get one point off of a hw assignment, now the highest grade that you can possibly get is a 99. I felt as though this hindered me from actually understanding the material and made me constantly question my ability in the course.

Professor Munoz is amazing. She's clear in the concepts that she explains during lecture, and is very open to helping students with more examples/explanations during office hours. I think a strength of this course is that the material, at least the way the professor teaches it, is so interesting and the professor is so passionate about the material that it makes you excited to learn

Professor Muoz is a gem. Take any of her classes that you can. She is knowledgeable and organized, yet approachable. As far as weaknesses, the class sometimes felt repetitive if you came in with a strong background in biology or anatomy. Also, having quizzes worth 2% of your grade each, without a curve meant that the single question could potentially alter your final grade.
The greatest strength of this course was Dr. Muoz. Her teaching was engaging and her passion for the subject was apparent.

Strength: both Professor Munoz and Brooke were extremely willing to help, very friendly, and always making an effort to accommodate to people's individual circumstances, which made it a great learning environment

Strengths: Both Prof. Muoz and Brooke were very sweet and responded promptly to emails. The material was fascinating. I thought the flexibility in answering 5 out of 6 questions was really refreshing in a biology class, and I appreciated Prof Muoz's understanding of the complex situation this semester raised.

Weaknesses: In its totality, the questions were poorly worded and vague. I think the vagueness of the questions negatively impacted my ability to showcase what I knew, and I think contributed to the significant exam stress (particularly in the second midterm) because I wasn't sure from what angle to approach the question. This was only compounded by questions that asked us to comment on the evolutionary origins of things that are still not fully explained in the literature. Additionally, I felt like the system of assigning partial credit was opaque and often seemed extreme, especially because literally any deduction on an assignment or exam could be directly tied to the final grade (e.g. a deduction of 0.5 would mean your entire grade in the class was docked 0.5 percent). I wish that we could see a rubric for how credit is assigned like in other classes which would help improve my understanding of the material for the future. Also, I wish that the class went over experimental design in much more detail because a significant portion of the final grade was dependent on designing experiments that we never really discussed how to design. Also, I felt like the homework itself was not particularly helpful for student learning because a) the questions for the assignment were often very vague, and b) only tangentially touched on what we discussed in class. It would have been far more helpful to have homework assignments geared towards to the material we learned in class, and perhaps don't grade so rigidly on correctness or allow for collaboration between students because so much of my time was spent not actually digesting the information, but rather trying to figure out how much to include or exclude in an answer because I didn't want to lose half a percent of my grade for an otherwise perfectly correct answer.

The strength of this course is Professor Munoz! She is such an engaging instructor, and I learned a lot/was more engaged just by the way that she taught the course. The material that she chose to highlight in lectures was also very cool--never boring! A challenge for this course (which I think was just a product of us holding the course virtually during 2020) was that the entire course was out of 100 points, so the grades you made on assignments directly impacted your overall course grade. In the future, it would be so great to have a little cushion in case someone has a bad experience right before an assessment that would negatively impact their performance.

The homework assignments could be completed without knowing any of the lecture material (they were short response questions to a scientific paper), which can be a strength of weakness depending on how you view it. A definite strength of the course is Professor Munoz-- she is so enthusiastic and excited to be there during the lectures, which is a totally different vibe from most Yale STEM professors.

strengths: lecture topics ranged widely in subject, numerous guest speakers presenting their own research in physiology, homework and exams had fair material and format (open book, untimed, relatively short), Prof Muoz's familiarity and engagement with the lecture material and taking questions

weaknesses: grading system is somewhat punitive in that each point on a homework assignment or quiz or exam corresponded to a whole point on the final average, and the sometimes vague or misguiding wording of questions only compounded this issue. textbook not helpful for the class material

While virtual learning is certainly not ideal for any course, I think the professor and TF made the virtual format for this course as engaging as possible. The powerpoint presentations were extremely easy to follow, and the professor always seemed extremely well prepared for each lecture. It is difficult to say how this course could be improved in any ways that are not directly related to the online format, which is out of the professor's control.

Lecture is extremely engaging where the speaking is complementary to the slides presented. The professor has done great preparation work. The professor combined the historic information and the up-to-date study of the field very well, and she is equally eloquent in teaching both of them. The assignments are appropriately assigned and the questions are carefully devised.

The assignment feedback system was hard to engage in. Sometimes remaining questions about grading to particular questions were unaddressed as the course moves fast. I wished the TA and professor can gather common questions from the assignment and address them quickly over the lecture.

The strength of this course was Professor Muoz. She made the course accessible, engaging, and filled with energy. Every topic she spoke on had me rapt with attention, furiously scribbling notes because it was all so interesting! The set-up of the course was great, the pacing was like other classes (which is too fast for me, but that's because of my attention issues). The guest lectures were outstanding, and truly elevated the course to a new level. The only weakness I can think of was the lack of reminders on when work was due: there was inconsistency on whether there would be a reminder in class or not. Several times I looked at the syllabus and realized there was work due THAT DAY. However, this may be more of an organizational challenge for me, although other courses were on top of reminding the class. Something that can be seen as both a strength and a weakness is that the exams draw from the material, but apply it in ways that you have not done before.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The recorded lectures were good!

I love the way the course is set up that you have 3 days to complete the exam. Especially during finals period, this helped take a lot of stress off of my shoulders and allowed me to complete the exams during my own time. I also think that the professor and TA were very accommodating whenever it came to students presenting problems/challenges due to the pandemic, which helped a lot.
Take-home exams and recorded online lectures were definitely a success. Discussion sections could be a little more organized and improved, but overall, the class was great.

I thought the flexibility with lecture and section attendance allowed me to cater my individual needs for the class to my schedule, which I greatly appreciated. In general, thank you, Prof Muoz, for validating our concerns about the world and about navigating classes during this tumultuous time.

Online lectures and section were great. Both Prof. Munoz and Brook worked really hard to make sure students were understanding concepts and receiving any support they needed. The online exams were also very well executed. The allotment of three days to complete each exam was well-thought-out and very generous.
open book and untimed assignments

I found it extremely helpful that each assignment was made available for several days (e.g., we had a three day period during which we could view, complete, and submit the midterm and final exams). Given the online format of everything, the extended time periods for every assignment certainly eased any nerves about having tech issues during assignment periods. Also, while in an in-person course, it is easy to ask the professor clarifying questions during an assignment of exam, this is obviously not quite as simple in the virtual format. Having several days to complete assignments gave all of the students a better chance at understanding the questions being asked, and gave the professor and TF time to answer questions over email- this made the course much more fair and made it so that the students could maximize their successfulness on each assignment. As for improvements, there were a few lectures that were not recorded, that were then missing from the Canvas page and could not be referenced for study purposes, so it would be beneficial if lectures could be automatically recorded so that no lectures are lost.

The live + recorded lecture mode worked really well. The raise hand, reaction buttons, and the chat box integrate pupils spontaneous emotions better than a live class, especially for introverts and internet savvy students.
I LOVED the in-class, ungraded polls. It spiced up the lectures, just like the videos played in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if you're interested in E&EB/animal behavior. While the professor is amazing and kind, the difficulty of the course material definitely increases towards the second half of the semester. The final was also much more difficult, in my opinion, than any of the previous assignments, so make sure that you ask questions about anything that you're not certain about.
It's a nice EEB class.
This was one of the BEST Stem classes I've ever taken at Yale. The professor really cares, the content is so interesting and out of the box.
Yes, anyone who is interested in comparative physiology (or physiology in general) should take this course
Yes, I would, for people with a firm background in biology and a desire to learn about numerous physiological phenomena.

Yes! I would recommend this course to any student interested in taking anatomy from more than just a human perspective. I'm pre-med, but I felt that taking this course actually gave me a broader view of all that anatomy can be, and I actually got much more excited about the subject material (and, eventually, studying for the MCAT) through this class than I believe I would have by strictly studying human anatomy.
Yes, if you're looking to major in E&EB or want to take a low-workload but interesting E&EB class on the side!

Physiology is a pre-req for many graduate programs as well as the E&EB major track 2, but overall the course material was interesting and Prof Nuoz communicated it well. I have qualms about the grading style (each point on an assignment = a point on your final average) and how it makes it hard to recover after one bad grade, but it also really makes you look over your answers. 

I took this course after Anatomy because it has a higher course number in the E&EB curriculum. In hindsight I would recommend taking this course first before anatomy, since there is a lot of overlap and my already learning material from anatomy definitely helped in this course. Still, you would probably be just fine in physiology having taken anatomy or not.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, whether they are studying biology or not. Any student with an interest in science/biological processes/evolution/behavior could benefit from this course.
Yes. It combines concepts of ecology and evolution well and is a good synthesis which helps applying multiple ideas to particular questions.

I would most DEFINITELY recommend this course to another student. The exams take you by surprise sometimes, but reading the textbook may help with that (I did not, which probably led to my surprise). This course is stuffed with info, and with about 6 assignments, 6 quizzes, and 2 exams, it is definitely manageable as an extra course. As a chemistry major, the material was very accessible, and even delved into some chemical concepts like diffusion (and some biomechanics which is AWESOME), so that was a major plus. I also took E&EB 290 before this, which helped a little. However, this course would not have helped if you took E&EB 295 after it, and so I recommend taking E&EB 290 first (it is strange this course is taught in fall and E&EB 290 is taught in spring).
